misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(b) will reorder the scores and automatically keep the corresponding names in array a matched to those scores, so that a[n-1] will still be the name of the student who has b[n-1] after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(b) sorts only the int[] b in place. It does not (and cannot) rearrange elements of a separate array a. Parallel arrays must be manually swapped together during sorting, or the data should be stored as paired objects (e.g., Student{name,score}) and sorted with a comparator. As written, after sorting b, indices no longer represent the same student across a and b, so a[n-1] is just the last input name, not the name of the max score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints a mismatched name-score pair for the top student whenever the highest score is not originally at index n-1. Example with sample input: b becomes [78,85,92] but a remains [Alice,Bob,Charlie], so output becomes "Charlie (92)" instead of "Bob (92)".

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are parallel (where index i in one relates to index i in the other), sorting one array will automatically trigger the same reordering in the other to maintain the logical pairing between elements.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are independent memory structures. There is no implicit or 'behind-the-scenes' link between two arrays even if they are the same length. Arrays.sort() operates strictly on the specific array reference provided, unaware of any intended logical relationship with other data structures. To sort parallel arrays, the programmer must implement a manual sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) and swap elements in both arrays simultaneously, or use an Object-Oriented approach (e.g., a Student class).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays automatically stay synchronized during sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also keep (or automatically rearrange) the corresponding names so that the name at index i still matches the score at index i after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(b) only reorders the elements inside array b. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate parallel array (a). After sorting b, the indices in b no longer correspond to the same students’ indices in a. To preserve the name-score pairing, the program must sort pairs together (e.g., swap both arrays during a custom sort, or use a Student class/records and sort objects), or find the max score index without sorting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints the last-entered name with the highest score, which may belong to a different student).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the scores array using Arrays.sort(b), the names array will automatically rearrange itself to maintain the original name-score pairings. They think the act of sorting one parallel array magically synchronizes the other array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to understand that arrays in Java are independent data structures. When Arrays.sort(b) is called, it sorts only the scores array in-place. The names array (a) remains completely unchanged. The correspondence between a[i] and b[i] is broken because the indices no longer represent the same logical pairings. The student's mental model treats parallel arrays as a single logical unit that sorts together, when in reality each array is independent and only the specified array is reordered.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' when it should output 'Top student: Bob (92)'. The score is correct (92 is indeed the highest), but the name is wrong because Charlie's original index (2) still contains 92 after sorting, yet Charlie originally had score 78, not 92.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since the 'a' (names) and 'b' (scores) arrays are intended to be parallel, performing a sort operation on the 'scores' array will automatically rearrange the 'names' array to maintain the correspondence between a student's name and their score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent memory structures. The Arrays.sort() method only manipulates the specific array passed as an argument. It has no awareness of other arrays that the programmer conceptually considers 'parallel'. When the scores array is sorted, the original index-based relationship with the names array is destroyed unless the names are manually swapped alongside the scores.
